description: From Middle English damaske, from Medieval Latin damascus, named after the city Damascus, where the fabric was originally made.

adjectives.description: damask (comparative more damask, superlative most damask)

entries.meaning: Of a grayish-pink color, like that of the damask rose.
examples: My cage has many rooms / Damask and dark / Nothing there sings, / Not even my lark.

entries.meaning: An ornate silk fabric originating from Damascus.
Linen so woven that a pattern is produced by the different directions of the thread, without contrast of colour.
A heavy woolen or worsted stuff with a pattern woven in the same way as the linen damask; made for furniture covering and hangings.
examples: Thus the red damask curtains which now shut out the fog-laden, drizzling atmosphere of the Marylebone Road, had cost a mere song, and yet they might have been warranted to last another thirty years. A great bargain also had been the excellent Axminster carpet which covered the floor; as, again, the arm-chair in which Bunting now sat forward, staring into the dull, small fire.

entries.meaning: The peculiar markings or water of such steel.
A damask rose, Rosa Ã— damascena.
A grayish-pink color, like that of the damask rose.

verbs.description: damask (third-person singular simple present damasks, present participle damasking, simple past and past participle damasked)

entries.meaning: To decorate or weave in damascene patterns
